thread.title: Canon Developing High-sensitivity Monitoring Camera

title: Canon Developing High-sensitivity Monitoring Camera
text:
The network camera under development (photo courtesy of Canon) [Click to enlarge image] An image taken by the network camera (left), and an image viewed with the naked eye (right) (photo courtesy of Canon) [Click to enlarge image] 
Canon Inc announced that it is currently developing a compact, high-sensitivity network camera capable of clearly showing a color image of a faraway object even at night or in a dark place where it is difficult to see the object with the naked eye. 
The camera will be useful for crime prevention and monitoring for natural disasters night and day, the company said. 
The network camera is being developed using optical technologies that Canon has been developing for many years and equipped with a large-diameter super-telephotographic lens that can collect a large amount of light. With the lens, even at the telephoto-end with a focal length longer than 600mm (135mm film equivalent), the F value, which indicates the brightness of the lens, is 2.4. 
Also, with the employment of an aspherical lens and UD (ultra-low dispersion) lens, aberration increased by the increase in diameter was reduced, and the size of the lens unit was also reduced. 
Conventional nighttime monitoring is possible only by applying infrared light over a limited distance or in the "night mode" (black-and-white photo mode). On the other hand, the new camera can recognize the face of a person 100m away from the camera in color even with a brightness of 0.08lx, which is equivalent to the brightness of moonlight, by combining the large-diameter lens, high-sensitivity sensor and high-performance video processing circuit, Canon said. 
Moreover, because the new camera has the super-telephotographic lens and an electrically-driven pan/tilt mechanism that controls the orientation of the camera, it can shoot an image of a wide area. It can be used for monitoring for natural disasters at rivers and harbors, monitoring cities from the roofs of buildings, recognizing the license plates of vehicles on roads, etc. It is suited for use in places where nighttime monitoring is required in addition to daytime monitoring. 
Canon aims to release the camera in 2016.
